nodes.text: Subjective, classroom-observation based teacher evaluation causally improves teacher effectiveness in ways that persist after the evaluation year

We estimate the effect of Cincinnati Public Schools Teacher Evaluation System (TES) using within-teacher over-time variation and teacher fixed effects comparing student math achievement before, during, and after a teacher's TES year

Analysis sample: 105 mid-career fourth through eighth grade math teachers hired 1993–1999 and 14,331 student-year observations from 2003–2004 to 2009–2010, combining TES observation timing and rubric scores with student test score data

Identification strategy models student end-of-year standardized math score as function of indicators for year of evaluation and postevaluation years, quadratic in teacher experience (capped), student covariates, grade-by-year fixed effects, and teacher fixed effects
Primary result: students taught after a teacher's TES year score on average 0.112 standard deviations higher in math than the same teacher's students before evaluation (statistically significant)
Students taught during a teacher's TES year show smaller positive gains (about 0.052 SD) that are generally positive but not always statistically significant

TES program description: year-long evaluation with three peer observations and one administrator observation, rubric based on Danielson framework, written feedback after observations, final summative scores in four domains, evaluators receive training
Evidence against major biases: event study shows no preexisting upward trend before evaluation and regressions find little change in observable student or teacher characteristics by evaluation timing

Robustness: results stable to alternative experience controls, using scheduled evaluation year, 2SLS instrumenting actual timing with scheduled timing, and restricting to teachers observed both before and after evaluation

Heterogeneity: postevaluation gains are larger for teachers with low preevaluation value-added, low TES scores, and those whose TES scores increased most during the TES year; math specialists show larger gains than self-contained teachers

Attrition analysis: most teachers (96 percent) remain in district after TES year; attrition patterns do not explain estimated postevaluation gains and weighted and restricted samples produce similar results

Mechanism (interpreted claim): evaluation likely improves long-run teacher performance by providing individualized performance information that enables learning, skill development, increased long-run effort, peer discussion, and self-reflection, though exact behavioral changes are not identified

Limitation: data do not identify precise mechanisms; effects may be larger for mid-career teachers or where personalized feedback is rare, and effects are not detected for reading achievement in this sample

Cost and general equilibrium consideration: TES incurs direct costs (about $7,500 per teacher per evaluation year) and opportunity costs when effective teachers serve as peer evaluators and are replaced in classrooms, but estimated student gains from evaluated teachers compare favorably to these costs

Conclusion: well-structured subjective classroom-observation evaluation can produce nontransient improvements in teacher effectiveness and thus serve as an effective form of professional development beyond selection or pay-for-performance models; findings may generalize to other settings where individualized performance information is scarce
